title: 105_hr4151
content: The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 is cited as the constitutional authority to regulate commerce and make laws necessary for executing government powers. It addresses identity theft. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 regulates commerce and makes laws to address identity theft. Section 1028(a) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include knowingly transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority to commit unlawful activities. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 amends Section 1028(a) of title 18, United States Code to include the transfer or use of another person's identification for unlawful activities. Penalties under Section 1028(b) are also amended to include offenses involving the transfer or use of means of identification. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 expands penalties for offenses involving the transfer or use of means of identification, including obtaining anything of value aggregating $1,000 or more in a year. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 increases penalties for offenses involving the transfer, use, or possession of identification documents, including fines or imprisonment for up to 20 years for crimes related to drug trafficking or violence. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 increases penalties for offenses involving identification documents, with fines or imprisonment up to 20 years for crimes related to drug trafficking or violence, including forfeiture of personal property used in the offense. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 increases penalties for offenses involving identification documents, with fines or imprisonment up to 20 years for crimes related to drug trafficking or violence, including forfeiture of personal property used in the offense. Additionally, in the case of any offense under subsection (a), there will be forfeiture to the United States of any personal property used or intended to be used to commit the offense. The circumstances under Section 1028(c) of title 18, United States Code, are amended to include that the production, transfer, possession, or use prohibited by this section must be in or affect interstate or foreign commerce, or involve means of identification, identification document, false identification document, or document-making implement. The definition of "document-making implement" in section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, includes any implement, electronic device, or computer hardware primarily used for making documents. The definition of "document-making implement" in section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, includes any implement, electronic device, or computer hardware primarily used for making identification documents. The term "means of identification" refers to any name or number that can be used to identify a specific individual, including name, social security number, and date of birth, as defined in the United States Code. The term "means of identification" includes names, numbers, and unique biometric or electronic data that can identify an individual. The term "personal identification card" refers to an ID issued by a government for identification purposes. The term "produce" includes altering, authenticating, or assembling. The term "State" encompasses all states in the US. The term "personal identification card" refers to an ID issued by a government for identification purposes. The term "produce" includes altering, authenticating, or assembling. The term "State" encompasses all states in the US. Any person who attempts or conspires to commit any offense under this section shall be subject to the same penalties. Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include penalties for attempting or conspiring to commit offenses related to personal identification cards. Forfeiture procedures for property involved in such offenses are also outlined. The forfeiture procedures for property involved in offenses related to personal identification cards are governed by the provisions of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970. The forfeiture procedures for property involved in offenses related to personal identification cards are governed by the provisions of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970. Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a rule of construction regarding identification documents. Chapter 47 of title 18 is also amended to reflect these changes. Amendment of Federal Sentencing Guidelines for Offenses under Section 1028 includes a rule of construction regarding identification documents. Chapter 47 of title 18 is also amended to reflect these changes. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors for consideration include the number of victims involved. The United States Sentencing Commission will consider the number of victims and means of identification involved in offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code when establishing penalties under Federal sentencing guidelines. The number of means of identification and value of loss are key factors in establishing penalties under Federal sentencing guidelines for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. The Federal sentencing guidelines consider factors such as the range of conduct covered by the offense, sentencing enhancements, statutory maximum penalties, and achieving the purposes of sentencing. The United States Sentencing Commission considers factors such as the extent to which Federal sentencing guidelines sentences are constrained by statutory maximum penalties, whether the guidelines achieve the purposes of sentencing, and any other relevant factors. SEC. 5. CENTRALIZED COMPLAINT AND CONSUMER EDUCATION SERVICE FOR VICTIMS OF IDENTITY THEFT. The Federal Trade Commission will establish procedures within a year to log complaints from individuals who believe their identification has been stolen, provide information to these individuals, and refer complaints to appropriate authorities. The Federal Trade Commission will establish procedures to log complaints from individuals who believe their identification has been stolen, provide information, and refer complaints to appropriate authorities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this section. Technical amendments to Title 18, United States Code. Technical amendments to Title 18, United States Code include changes related to criminal forfeiture procedures and the inclusion of economic espionage and theft of trade secrets as predicate offenses for wire interception. The Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 (21 U.S.C. 853) is amended. Economic espionage and theft of trade secrets are added as predicate offenses for wire interception in Title 18, United States Code. SEC. 7. REDACTION OF ETHICS REPORTS FILED BY JUDICIAL OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES. Section 105(b) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to allow for redaction of reports filed by certain individuals if revealing personal information could endanger them. Redactions are only permitted to protect the individual and as long as the danger persists. Section 105(b) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 allows for redaction of reports filed by individuals to protect them from danger. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts must submit an annual report on the redacted reports and individuals affected. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 allows for redaction of reports to protect individuals from danger. The Judicial Conference, in consultation with the Department of Justice, will issue regulations on when redaction is appropriate and the procedures for redaction. This provision expires on December 31, 2001, and applies to filings through calendar year 2001.
